topic: Governing Religion in the Middle East

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
International Studies 395: Governing Religion in the Middle East: Minorities, Rights, and the Rule of Law

"Is This the End of Christianity in the Middle East?" Eliza Griswold's July 2015 New York Times headline typifies a growing interest in how states across the Middle East manage religious pluralism. While observers suggest that religious minorities are at greater risk of persecution due to the global rise of Islamist political movements, there is little discussion of the historical conditions that constituted minority status long before such movements became a phenomenon. Students will use readings from political science, history, legal studies, anthropology, and popular culture to think critically about the nation-state and the concept of "minority," a term which emerged historically only after World War I. This seminar will focus on the colonial and contemporary histories of religious rights, citizenship, nationalism, and sectarianism in Egypt, Turkey, Lebanon, Syria, and Iraq, and will draw on comparative cases beyond the region.
